presentation.title: Sediment regulation
presentation.runninghead: Benefits related to retention and removal of sediment

page.name: Sediment regulation
page.title: Model coverage and general information
page.description:
Erosion and sedimentation are major global problems that impose a high cost on the functioning of ecosystems and ecosystem service delivery. Excessive erosion and sedimentation have serious negative impacts on economic sectors including agriculture, water supply, electric power generation, and navigation. Excessive sediment delivery can also have negative impacts on coastal and nearshore marine ecosystems and the services they provide. At the same time, natural sediment delivery can be beneficial process in some contexts, and the disruption of natural sediment delivery can thus have negative impacts. For example, reduced sediment delivery to deltas can lead to loss of coastal wetlands and the critical services they provide.

Spatial modeling of sedimentation has frequently used models such as the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE), Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE), or Spatially Explicit Delivery Model (SEDMOD). USLE and RUSLE multiply five coefficients – rainfall runoff erosivity, soil erodibility, slope steepness and length, cover management, and conservation practice – to estimate soil loss over a given area and time (e.g., tons sediment/ha-yr). Spatial data for soil loss and RUSLE coefficients are available, and using these deterministic models, where appropriate, can reduce our reliance on ad hoc probabilistic models. However, USLE and RUSLE have several well-known limitations: 1) they apply only to sheet erosion versus linear or mass erosion; 2) they have only been tested in regions with 1-20% slopes and are inappropriate for areas with steeper slopes or young mountains where greater erosion is possible; 3) energy-rainfall relationships have been best tested for the U.S. Great Plains, meaning that locally appropriate rainfall runoff erosivity coefficients must be carefully developed and applied; 4) data are not valid for individual storms but averages; and 5) The equations simplify interactions between factors to attempt to isolate the relative effects of each. Thus USLE/RUSLE are likely most appropriate in level to moderately hilly landscapes with similar physical and ecological characteristics as the central United States; different models may be more appropriate in other parts of the world. By using ARIES' internal rule base to select the appropriate models, we can apply the RUSLE model and data on more level landscapes and regionally appropriate ad hoc erosion models for steeper slopes or areas where RUSLE is known to be inadequate.

Along with modeling and mapping sources of waterborne sediment, we model sink regions where sediment deposition occurs, along with users who either value beneficial sediment or would be harmed by either delivery of excess sediment or the presence of excessively turbid waterways. Sediment regulation can thus be classified as either a provisioning or preventive service, depending on whether the user benefits from or is harmed by sediment delivery. Running the sediment flow model allows the user to map spatial connections between sources of sediment, areas that promote sediment deposition, and users that benefit from or are harmed by sediment delivery. In addition to these beneficiaries, vegetation can provide the in situ benefit of erosion control for farmers or other beneficiaries who want to avoid soil loss from their lands. This benefit can be estimated by simply running the erosion source model in the present state and with either no vegetation or a planned (scenario) vegetation type, without needing to run a flow model. The influence of vegetation on avoided soil erosion is thus calculated for these beneficiaries.
